Content:
After a little bit of frustration, I've figured out the issue I've been having with saving/reading to a config.json and thought that I'd spell out the solution here in case anyone ever follows the posts.  I wanted to read some simple config values from a json. Zedmag very generously pointed me to the code that he uses in his flyingbirds mod. I adapted it correctly to read a single integer value. Not surprisingly given that Zedmag's code was production, the adapted code worked perfectly. However, when I subsequently tried to add values to the .json, the script would not read them. It was very frustrating even though I received lots of good help and advice. As it turns out the problem was in these two lines of  Zedmag's code as I had adapted it:
```private static const string configPath = "$profile:\\RationalBases\\FB_Settings.json";
private static const string configRoot = "$profile:\\RationalBases\\";    ```
The problem wasn't with the code itself but that I used it without really understanding it. I wasn't paying attention to whether my code was running on the server or the client. Data saves in different locations depending on where its run. `.\serverprofile` folder for the server and  `.\appdata\local\dayz` folder for the client. The problem was that I was changing the values `.\serverprofile`. Once I cleared this up, the code works as expected and I can add new config settings to my hearts content. üôÇ The tl;dr is make sure that you *understand* the code that you crib from someone else. I still don't understand how/why these two folders are semi-linked. Maybe a more experienced coder here can shed light on that.

The distance is obtained by calculating the length of the resulting vector. You would use vector subtraction, for example, if you were trying to calculate a "look" vector to see if a game object is looking at the player. In the Enforce script by default all variables are weak references, ref keyword is marking that variable is strong reference. In some special cases, variables are strong references by default

local variables inside functions
function arguments
function return value
and are released after their scope ends.

While an object is stored in at least one strong reference, it's being kept alive. When the last strong reference is destroyed or overwritten, the object is destroyed and all other (only weak refs left) references are set to NULL. When an object is deleted manually by delete command (e.g., 'delete a;'), it is deleted immediately ignoring reference count, and all references (weak and strong) are set to NULL.`

Author: kpro1982
Content: It is another way to let the compiler know what to do with the memory that your objects are using up. Normally, the compiler will release the memory (i.e. delete the object) when the scope ends.  The `ref keyword` tells the compiler to hold on to it until that specific reference is deleted.  The result is that memory may be accessible to you in other parts of your code, which could be useful.  But it also means that it can hang around way longer than you need it to choking the resources of the server. I think the rule of thumb around here (others can chime in if I'm wrong here) is to limit the usage of ref until you really need it.  If you search on this discord you'll see some advice like that.
